present_perfect_continuous.title: Present Perfect Continuous
present_perfect_continuous.subtitle: Actions continuing up to now.
present_perfect_continuous.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Pres. Perfect Continuous

1. Concept: Focus on activity duration (started in past, still happening or just finished).

2. Structure:

Have/Has + been + Verb-ing

3. Usage:

  • Duration: "I have been waiting for 2 hours." (I am still waiting).
  • Visible Result: "I am wet because I have been running." (Just finished).

explorer.correctSentence: I have been waiting for you
She has been working all day
They have been playing tennis
We have been studying English
He has been sleeping for 10 hours
It has been raining since morning
You have been cooking all morning
I have been reading this book
She has been crying
We have been talking about you

scholar.correctSentence: How long have you been learning English
She has not been feeling well lately
Have you been waiting long
I have not been exercising enough
He has been watching TV since 9am
They have been living here for too long
My phone has been ringing all day
What have you been doing all day
The neighbors have been making noise
I have been trying to call you

specialist.original: I am out of breath. I (run).
specialist.correctSentence: I have been running
specialist.hint: Present result of recent continuous action.

specialist.correctSentence: What have you been doing
She has been teaching here for 20 years

specialist.original: Use Simple if lasting (live/work): I (live) here all my life.
specialist.correctSentence: I have lived here all my life
specialist.hint: Permanent state = Simple (Check exceptions). Actually 'have been living' is also fine, but Simple is preferred for 'all my life'. Limit complexity: Let's stick to Continuous topic examples. 'I (live) here recently' -> 'I have been living'...

specialist.original: I (live) out of a suitcase recently.
specialist.correctSentence: I have been living out of a suitcase recently

specialist.original: Who (eat) my cookies? The jar is empty!
specialist.correctSentence: Who has been eating my cookies
specialist.hint: Evidence of activity (crumbs?) vs finished result (empty). If empty -> 'Who has eaten'. If half empty -> 'Who has been eating'. The prompt says empty... let's change prompt to 'There are crumbs'.

specialist.original: Who (eat) my cookies? There are crumbs everywhere.
specialist.correctSentence: Who has been eating my cookies
I have been thinking about changing jobs

specialist.original: He (drive) for 10 hours so he looks tired.
specialist.correctSentence: He has been driving for 10 hours so he looks tired

specialist.original: We (look) for a house for months.
specialist.correctSentence: We have been looking for a house for months
Have you been crying

specialist.original: Sorry I'm late. I (chat) with Mark.
specialist.correctSentence: I have been chatting with Mark

pp_simple_vs_continuous.title: Present Perfect: Simple vs. Continuous
pp_simple_vs_continuous.subtitle: Completed Result vs. Ongoing Activity.
pp_simple_vs_continuous.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Pres. Perfect Simple vs Cont.

1. Simple (Result/Quantity): "I have written 3 emails." (Finished quantity).

2. Continuous (Duration/Activity): "I have been writing emails all morning." (Activity focus).

Tip: Always use SIMPLE for stative verbs ("I have known", NOT "have been knowing").

explorer.original: I (clean) the car. It looks new.
explorer.correctSentence: I have cleaned the car

explorer.original: I (clean) the car for an hour.
explorer.correctSentence: I have been cleaning the car for an hour

explorer.original: She (write) a book. It is finished.
explorer.correctSentence: She has written a book
She has been writing a book this year
We have walked 10 kilometers
We have been walking for 2 hours
He has eaten the sandwich
He has been eating all day
They have played that game three times
They have been playing games since noon

scholar.correctSentence: Look Someone has broken that window
Have you been running
I have known her for years

scholar.original: I (read) this book. I'm on page 50.
scholar.correctSentence: I have been reading this book

scholar.original: I (read) this book. It was great!
scholar.correctSentence: I have read this book
He has drunk three coffees
He has been drinking coffee all morning
I have been cooking
I have cooked
How long have you had this car

specialist.correctSentence: I have liked jazz since I was 20

specialist.original: The kitchen is wet. (you/wash) the floor?
specialist.correctSentence: Have you been washing the floor
Have you washed it

specialist.original: I (peel) onions, that's why I'm crying.
specialist.correctSentence: I have been peeling onions
I have peeled ten pounds of onions
She has always loved horses

specialist.original: What (you/do) with my phone? It's broken.
specialist.correctSentence: What have you done with my phone

specialist.original: What (you/do) on my phone? The screen is warm.
specialist.correctSentence: What have you been doing on my phone

specialist.original: We (paint) the room. It looks better.
specialist.correctSentence: We have painted the room

specialist.original: We (paint) the room. We are halfway done.
specialist.correctSentence: We have been painting the room

past_perfect_simple.title: Past Perfect Simple
past_perfect_simple.subtitle: The 'Past before the Past'.
past_perfect_simple.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Past Perfect

1. Concept: "The past before the past."

2. Structure:

Had + Past Participle (V3)

3. Usage: When two things happened in the past, use Past Perfect for the first action.

✅ "When I arrived (2), the train had left (1)."

explorer.correctSentence: When I arrived she had left
He had finished his work before 5pm
I was hungry because I had not eaten
They had gone home before it rained

explorer.original: She told me she (see) the movie.
explorer.correctSentence: She told me she had seen the movie

explorer.original: The party (start) when I got there.
explorer.correctSentence: The party had started when I got there

explorer.original: He (lose) his key so he couldn't enter.
explorer.correctSentence: He had lost his key so he couldn't enter
We had studied this before

explorer.original: The rain (stop) by the time we left.
explorer.correctSentence: The rain had stopped by the time we left
I realized I had forgotten my phone

scholar.original: The train (leave) when we arrived at the station.
scholar.correctSentence: The train had left when we arrived at the station

scholar.original: I (never/see) such a giant before that day.
scholar.correctSentence: I had never seen such a giant before that day
He had already left when I called

scholar.original: She was tired because she (work) hard.
scholar.correctSentence: She was tired because she had worked hard
scholar.hint: Cause (Simple OK, Continuous better usually, but Simple acceptable for completion).

scholar.correctSentence: Had you eaten before you came
By 2010 he had written five books

scholar.original: I didn't have money because I (lose) my wallet.
scholar.correctSentence: I had lost my wallet
She said she had never been to Paris

scholar.original: After I (wash) the car, I drove it.
scholar.correctSentence: After I had washed the car I drove it
We had just finished dinner when he knocked

specialist.original: It was the first time I (meet) him.
specialist.correctSentence: It was the first time I had met him
specialist.hint: First time in past context => Past Perfect.

specialist.original: I returned to the town where I (grow) up.
specialist.correctSentence: I returned to the town where I had grown up

specialist.original: The grass was yellow because it (not/rain) all summer.
specialist.correctSentence: The grass was yellow because it had not rained all summer

specialist.original: He refused to go until he (finish).
specialist.correctSentence: He refused to go until he had finished

specialist.original: By the time the police arrived, the thief (escape).
specialist.correctSentence: By the time the police arrived the thief had escaped

specialist.original: I recognized him. I (see) him on TV.
specialist.correctSentence: I recognized him I had seen him on TV

specialist.original: She felt sick because she (eat) too much.
specialist.correctSentence: She felt sick because she had eaten too much

specialist.original: If I (know), I would have told you.
specialist.correctSentence: If I had known I would have told you
specialist.hint: Third Conditional (Preview or usage in Past context).

specialist.original: Hardly (I/start) work when the phone rang.
specialist.correctSentence: Hardly had I started work when the phone rang

specialist.original: No sooner (we/arrive) than it began to rain.
specialist.correctSentence: No sooner had we arrived than it began to rain

past_perfect_vs_past_simple.title: Past Perfect vs. Past Simple
past_perfect_vs_past_simple.subtitle: Order of past events.
past_perfect_vs_past_simple.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Past Perfect vs. Past Simple

1. Sequence matters:

  • Sequence clear: "I opened the door and entered." (Both Past Simple).
  • Sequence emphasized: "I realized that I had lost my wallet." (Lost BEFORE realized).

explorer.correctSentence: Before I slept I had read a book
After she had eaten she felt sick

explorer.original: I (lose) the key so I (cannot) open the door.
explorer.correctSentence: I had lost the key so I could not open the door
The movie had started when we arrived
He was tired because he had run
Since she had not studied she failed
The grass was yellow because it had not rained
I thanked him for what he had done
When I got there everyone had gone
She realized she had made a mistake

scholar.original: By the time we (get) to the cinema, the film (start).
scholar.correctSentence: By the time we got to the cinema the film had started

scholar.original: I (go) to bed as soon as I (finish) my work.
scholar.correctSentence: I went to bed as soon as I had finished my work

scholar.original: She (be) sad because she (break) her doll.
scholar.correctSentence: She was sad because she had broken her doll

scholar.original: We (eat) at that restaurant before we (go) to the theater.
scholar.correctSentence: We had eaten at that restaurant before we went to the theater

scholar.original: When he (open) the box, he saw what he (buy).
scholar.correctSentence: When he opened the box he saw what he had bought
I had never seen him before we met yesterday

scholar.original: The teacher (ask) if we (do) our homework.
scholar.correctSentence: The teacher asked if we had done our homework

scholar.original: The house (be) quiet. Everybody (go) to sleep.
scholar.correctSentence: The house was quiet Everybody had gone to sleep

scholar.original: After he (paint) the wall, it (look) new.
scholar.correctSentence: After he had painted the wall it looked new

scholar.original: Only after I (post) the letter, I (realize) the error.
scholar.correctSentence: Only after I had posted the letter I realized the error

specialist.correctSentence: We did not get a table because we had not booked

specialist.original: I (be) sorry that I (not/be) nicer to him.
specialist.correctSentence: I was sorry that I had not been nicer to him
Until she explained I had not understood
specialist.hint: Or 'Until she explained I didn't understand'. 'Had not understood' is logical up to that point.

specialist.original: Use Past Simple/Perfect for clarity: I (open) the door and (see) a cat.
specialist.correctSentence: I opened the door and saw a cat
specialist.hint: Sequence of consecutive events (no gap) = Past Simple.

specialist.original: When I (open) the door, the cat (already/jump) out.
specialist.correctSentence: When I opened the door the cat had already jumped out
He admitted that he had stolen the money

specialist.original: The road (be) blocked because a tree (fall).
specialist.correctSentence: The road was blocked because a tree had fallen

specialist.original: When they (get) home, they found that thieves (break) in.
specialist.correctSentence: When they got home they found that thieves had broken in

specialist.original: I (hope) to see her, but she (leave).
specialist.correctSentence: I had hoped to see her but she had left
Before I knew it he had run away

future_continuous.title: Future Continuous
future_continuous.subtitle: Actions in progress in the future.
future_continuous.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Future Continuous

1. Concept: Action in progress at a specific future time.

2. Structure:

Will be + Verb-ing

3. Examples:
✅ "At 8pm tomorrow, I will be watching TV."
✅ "Don't call at 7, I will be driving."

explorer.correctSentence: I will be waiting for you at 5
She will be working tomorrow morning
They will be playing tennis then

explorer.original: We (fly) to Paris this time tomorrow.
explorer.correctSentence: We will be flying to Paris this time tomorrow
He will be sleeping when you arrive
It will be raining all day tomorrow
You will be missing the sun
I will be cooking dinner at 6
She will be studying tonight
We will be having fun

scholar.correctSentence: Don't call at 8 I will be eating dinner

scholar.original: This time next week, I (lie) on the beach.
scholar.correctSentence: This time next week I will be lying on the beach
Will you be using the car tomorrow
He will not be playing with us
What will you be doing in ten years
We will be staying at the Ritz
scholar.hint: Arrangement (Will be -ing often sounds like fixed plan too).

scholar.original: I'll see you at the party. I (wear) a red dress.
scholar.correctSentence: I will be wearing a red dress
They will be arriving soon
scholar.hint: Standard Future or 'Will be arriving' for strict schedule.

scholar.correctSentence: The band will be playing all night
She will be waiting at the station

specialist.original: Try to come early. We (wait) for you.
specialist.correctSentence: We will be waiting for you
I suppose you will be working late again
Next year I will be studying math

specialist.original: Will you be home? No, I (shop).
specialist.correctSentence: No I will be shopping
Don't worry she will not be waiting long

specialist.original: Come any time. Using simple vs continuous: I (watch) TV. (Meaning I am in the middle of it).
specialist.correctSentence: I will be watching TV

specialist.original: In an hour, we (fly) over the Alps.
specialist.correctSentence: In an hour we will be flying over the Alps
Who will be driving this time

specialist.original: My parents (visit) so I can't come.
specialist.correctSentence: My parents will be visiting so I can't come
Surely they will not be expecting us this early

modals_obligation.title: Modals of Obligation
modals_obligation.subtitle: Must vs Have to vs Should (Review & Nuance).
modals_obligation.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Modals of Obligation

1. Must vs. Have to (Review): Must (Internal), Have to (External).

2. Should / Ought to: Advice / Recommendation ("You ought to apologize").

3. Had to: Obligation in the PAST ("I had to leave early yesterday"). Must has no past form!

explorer.correctSentence: I must call my mom
You have to wear a uniform
She should study more
Drivers must stop at red lights
explorer.hint: Strong rule/law (Must often used in written rules).

explorer.correctSentence: We don't have to pay
You must not smoke here
He has to work on Sundays
You should not eat that
They have to leave now
I must go

scholar.original: In this country, you (have to/carry) ID.
scholar.correctSentence: In this country you have to carry ID

scholar.original: I (must/see) that movie! Everyone loves it.
scholar.correctSentence: I must see that movie

scholar.original: You (don't/have to/come) if you don't want.
scholar.correctSentence: You don't have to come if you don't want
You must not forget your keys
We ought to leave soon
Passengers must remain seated
Do I have to sign this
She doesn't have to wear makeup
scholar.hint: Correction to make sense: She doesn't have to wear makeup.

scholar.correctSentence: You really should try this cake
Doctors have to work long hours

specialist.original: I (had to/wait) ages for the bus.
specialist.correctSentence: I had to wait ages for the bus
You didn't have to bring a gift

specialist.original: To get the job, you (have to/speak) French.
specialist.correctSentence: To get the job you have to speak French
We must not tell anyone about the party
I must remember to email him
You should have seen his face
She should have studied harder
Did you have to pay for it
He didn't need to come
You ought not to allow that

modals_probability.title: Modals of Probability
modals_probability.subtitle: May, Might, Could, Must, Can't.
modals_probability.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Modals of Deduction

1. Certainty (True): Must ("He is running, he must be late").

2. Certainty (False): Can't ("It can't be true!").

3. Possibility: May / Might / Could ("It might rain").

explorer.correctSentence: It might rain later
She must be tired
That can't be John
We could go to the park
He may come tomorrow
You must be joking
It may not be true
They might be lost
This could be dangerous
It can't be 5 o'clock already

scholar.original: Where's Tom? He (might/be) in his room.
scholar.correctSentence: He might be in his room

scholar.original: Look at his car. He (must/have) money.
scholar.correctSentence: He must have money
She might be sleeping
It can't be easy to learn Chinese
There could be a mistake
They may not arrive on time
You must be exhausted

scholar.original: Whose coat is this? It (could/be) Jane's.
scholar.correctSentence: It could be Jane's

scholar.original: Is that a cat? No, it (must/be) a dog.
scholar.correctSentence: No it must be a dog
It might rain

specialist.original: The phone is ringing. It (might/be) Mom.
specialist.correctSentence: It might be Mom

specialist.original: He failed the test? He (can't/have) studied.
specialist.correctSentence: He can't have studied

specialist.original: The street is wet. It (must/have) rained.
specialist.correctSentence: It must have rained

specialist.original: She is late. She (might/have) missed the bus.
specialist.correctSentence: She might have missed the bus

specialist.original: Where is my bag? I (could/have) left it home.
specialist.correctSentence: I could have left it home
He must have forgotten
You can't have seen a ghost
It may have been a mistake
She must be working late
They could not have known

reported_speech.title: Reported Speech
reported_speech.subtitle: Statements: He said that...
reported_speech.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Reported Speech

1. Concept: Reporting what someone said.

2. The Shift (Back in Time):

  • Present "I am happy" -> Past "He said he was happy."
  • Past "I arrived" -> Past Perfect "He said he had arrived."
  • Will "I will call" -> Would "He said he would call."

explorer.original: "I like pizza." -> He said he (like) pizza.
explorer.correctSentence: He said he liked pizza

explorer.original: "I am happy." -> She said she (be) happy.
explorer.correctSentence: She said she was happy

explorer.original: "We work here." -> They said they (work) there.
explorer.correctSentence: They said they worked there

explorer.original: "I can swim." -> He said he (could) swim.
explorer.correctSentence: He said he could swim
He said it was raining

explorer.original: "I don't know." -> She said she (didn't) know.
explorer.correctSentence: She said she didn't know

explorer.original: "We live in London." -> They said they (live) in London.
explorer.correctSentence: They said they lived in London

explorer.original: "I will call." -> He said he (would) call.
explorer.correctSentence: He said he would call

explorer.original: "I have a car." -> She said she (have) a car.
explorer.correctSentence: She said she had a car

explorer.original: "My name is Bond." -> He said his name (be) Bond.
explorer.correctSentence: He said his name was Bond

scholar.correctSentence: He said he had eaten

scholar.original: "I bought a car." -> She said she (buy) a car.
scholar.correctSentence: She said she had bought a car
He said he was working

scholar.original: "I must go." -> She said she (have to) go.
scholar.correctSentence: She said she had to go
He said he had been sleeping
scholar.hint: Past Cont -> Past Perf Cont (or Past Cont stays same sometimes, but let's teach change). Or simply 'was sleeping' -> 'had been sleeping'.

scholar.original: "I will be there." -> She said she (be) there.
scholar.correctSentence: She said she would be there

scholar.original: "I can help." -> He said he (could) help.
scholar.correctSentence: He said he could help

scholar.original: "We have been waiting." -> They said they (wait).
scholar.correctSentence: They said they had been waiting
scholar.hint: Pres Perf Cont -> Past Perf Cont.

scholar.original: "I don't like it." -> She said she (not/like) it.
scholar.correctSentence: She said she didn't like it

scholar.original: "I will do it tomorrow." -> He said he would do it (the next day).
scholar.correctSentence: He said he would do it the next day
scholar.hint: Time change: tomorrow -> the next day.

specialist.original: "I may come." -> He said he (might) come.
specialist.correctSentence: He said he might come

specialist.original: "I saw him yesterday." -> She said she (see) him the day before.
specialist.correctSentence: She said she had seen him the day before
specialist.hint: Past Simple -> Past Perf + Time change.

specialist.original: "I won't tell anyone." -> He promised he (not/tell) anyone.
specialist.correctSentence: He promised he wouldn't tell anyone

specialist.original: "You should study." -> He told me I (should) study.
specialist.correctSentence: He told me I should study

specialist.original: "I haven't seen her." -> He said he (not/see) her.
specialist.correctSentence: He said he hadn't seen her

specialist.original: "If I were you..." -> He said if he (be) me...
specialist.correctSentence: He said if he were me

specialist.original: "I came holding a flower." -> He said he (come) holding a flower.
specialist.correctSentence: He said he had come holding a flower

specialist.original: "This is my house." -> He said (that) was his house.
specialist.correctSentence: He said that was his house

specialist.original: "I am going to leave." -> He said he (be) going to leave.
specialist.correctSentence: He said he was going to leave

specialist.original: "Why are you late?" -> He asked me why I (be) late.
specialist.correctSentence: He asked me why I was late

passive_voice.title: Passive Voice
passive_voice.subtitle: Be + Past Participle.
passive_voice.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Passive Voice

1. Concept: Action is more important than who did it.

2. Structure:

Be (any tense) + Past Participle (V3)

3. Examples:
✅ Active: "Someone built the house."
✅ Passive: "The house was built (by someone)."

explorer.correctSentence: The room is cleaned every day
The car was repaired yesterday
English is spoken here
The house was built in 1990
My bike was stolen last week
Lunch is served at 12
The letters were written by me
The cake was eaten by the dog
Books are made of paper
I was invited to the party

scholar.correctSentence: The work must be done by Friday
It can be seen from here
The house is being painted right now
The keys have not been found yet
This song was sung by Elvis
The trash should be taken out
We were woken up by a noise

scholar.original: A lot of coffee (drink) in Italy.
scholar.correctSentence: A lot of coffee is drunk in Italy

scholar.original: How many cars (make) in this factory?
scholar.correctSentence: How many cars are made in this factory
America was discovered by Columbus

specialist.correctSentence: I was not told about the meeting
He hates being kept waiting
The problem was being discussed when I arrived
The robbers will be caught soon
This needs to be fixed
specialist.hint: Passive Infinitive (or needs fixing). Let's use 'to be fixed' or change prompt. Prompt: 'needs to be fixed'.

specialist.correctSentence: I remember being given a toy
She wants to be taken seriously
He was said to be a spy
It is said that he is rich
Nothing can be done about it

relative_clauses_defining.title: Relative Clauses (Defining)
relative_clauses_defining.subtitle: Essential information: Who, Which, That, Whose.
relative_clauses_defining.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Defining Relative Clauses

1. Concept: Essential information to identify which one.

2. Rule: No commas.

✅ "The man who lives next door is nice." (Tells us WHICH man).

3. Omission: You can drop 'who/that/which' if it enters the OBJECT ("The book [that] I bought").

explorer.original: The book (which/who) is on the table.
explorer.correctSentence: The book which is on the table
The man who lives here
The car that I bought
The girl whose bag is red

explorer.original: This is the place (where/that) we met.
explorer.correctSentence: This is the place where we met
The time when we start
The actor who won the Oscar
The cake that is delicious
The keys that are lost

explorer.original: Do you know the boy (who/which) is crying?
explorer.correctSentence: Do you know the boy who is crying

scholar.correctSentence: The friend I called yesterday
The house we live in
The reason why I am late
Everything that happened was true
The doctor who treated me
The job that I want
The woman to whom I spoke
The hotel at which we stayed
The day on which we met
Someone whose name I forgot

specialist.correctSentence: The film about which we talked
The colleague whose car broke down
The painting you are looking at
The chair he is sitting on
The man I introduced you to
All I want is you
There is no one who can help
He is the best player that ever lived
Is there anything I can do
The methods by which they work

gerunds_infinitives_complex.title: Gerunds & Infinitives (Complex)
gerunds_infinitives_complex.subtitle: Stop to do vs Stop doing, etc.
gerunds_infinitives_complex.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Complex Gerunds/Infinitives

1. Change in Meaning:

  • Remember doing: Memory of past ("I remember locking the door").
  • Remember to do: Task ("Remember to lock the door").
  • Stop doing: Quit ("He stopped smoking").
  • Stop to do: Pause ("He stopped to smoke").

explorer.correctSentence: I stopped smoking
I stopped to buy bread
Remember to lock the door
I remember locking it
Don't forget to call
I'll never forget seeing her
Try opening the window
Try to be quiet
I regret to tell you
I regret telling him

scholar.correctSentence: It's no use complaining
It is worth seeing
I can't help laughing
I'd rather stay home
You had better go
He made me cry
Let him go
She encouraged me to try
We prevented him from falling
I urge you to reconsider

specialist.correctSentence: I suggest waiting
I suggest that he wait
She admitted stealing it
He denied being there
I prefer walking to driving
I would prefer to stay
This needs washing

specialist.original: He went on (talk) about his illness.
specialist.correctSentence: He went on talking about his illness

specialist.original: He went on (talk) about his job (next topic).
specialist.correctSentence: He went on to talk about his job
specialist.hint: Ideally 'to talk' for change of topic. Let's assume text distinction.

specialist.correctSentence: There is no point in arguing

conditionals_review_second.title: Conditionals (0, 1, 2)
conditionals_review_second.subtitle: Review of Zero/First, Intro to Second.
conditionals_review_second.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Conditional Review

Zero (Fact): If + Present, ... Present ("If heat, it melts").

First (Real): If + Present, ... Will ("If rain, I will stay").

Second (Unreal): If + Past, ... Would ("If I had money, I would travel").

explorer.original: If I (have) money, I (buy) a car.
explorer.correctSentence: If I had money I would buy a car
If it rains I will stay home
If you heat ice it melts
If I were you I would go
If he studies he will pass
If I won the lottery I would fly
Water boils if you cook it
I would help if I could
If she calls tell her
What would you do if you lost

scholar.original: If I (know) his number, I (call) him.
scholar.correctSentence: If I knew his number I would call him
Unless you run you will miss the train

scholar.correctSentence: If you mix blue and yellow you get green

used_to_would.title: Used To vs. Would
used_to_would.subtitle: Past States vs. Repeated Actions.
used_to_would.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Used To vs. Would

1. Used To: Past habits AND States ("I used to be shy").

2. Would: Past habits ONLY (Nostalgia). NO States!

✅ "We would play all day." (Action -> OK)
❌ "I would have a dog." (State 'Have' -> Wrong, must use 'Used to').

explorer.correctSentence: I used to live in Paris
We would play soccer every day
She used to be a teacher
He used to have a car
Grandma would bake cookies
I used to like candy
They would go to the beach
He used to know the answer
Every summer we would swim
I used to think he was nice

scholar.correctSentence: There used to be a cinema here

scholar.original: We (used to/would) sit by the fire.
scholar.correctSentence: We would sit by the fire
I used to love chocolate
He would often visit us
My dad used to have a beard

scholar.original: Years ago, I (used to/work) at a bank.
scholar.correctSentence: I used to work at a bank
scholar.hint: State (Long term) -> Used to preferred, tough line. Let's stick to simple rule: Work = State in this context?

scholar.correctSentence: On Sunday we would go to church
She used to believe in ghosts

scholar.original: When I was young, I (would/read) for hours.
scholar.correctSentence: When I was young I would read for hours
Did you use to play tennis

specialist.correctSentence: I used to understand Greek

specialist.original: Whenever he came, he (would) bring gifts.
specialist.correctSentence: Whenever he came he would bring gifts
She used to be very shy

specialist.original: I (would) always wake up early in summer.
specialist.correctSentence: I would always wake up early in summer

specialist.original: We (used to) live in a small flat.
specialist.correctSentence: We used to live in a small flat

specialist.original: Every Christmas, we (would) decorate the tree.
specialist.correctSentence: Every Christmas we would decorate the tree
I never used to like olives
He would talk for hours

specialist.original: That house (used to) belong to me.
specialist.correctSentence: That house used to belong to me

specialist.original: Use 'used to' for discontinuity: I (used to) smoke, but I stopped.
specialist.correctSentence: I used to smoke but I stopped
